Home / Services / Oral Surgery

Tooth Extractions

Safe and comfortable tooth removal for severely infected or damaged teeth, followed by replacement options to restore your smile.

When Removal is Necessary

Sometimes a tooth is too severely infected or damaged to be saved. We perform safe, comfortable extractions using local anesthetic, and always discuss replacement options to restore your smile and oral function.

When Tooth Extraction is Needed

Common Reasons for Extraction

  • !

    Severe Infection

    Infection has spread beyond what root canal therapy can treat

  • !

    Extensive Decay

    Tooth structure too damaged to support a filling or crown

  • !

    Severe Fracture

    Crack or break extends below the gum line

  • !

    Advanced Gum Disease

    Tooth has lost too much supporting bone structure

Other Situations

  • i

    Orthodontic Treatment

    Creating space for proper tooth alignment

  • i

    Impacted Teeth

    Teeth that cannot properly emerge through the gums

  • i

    Overcrowding

    Too many teeth for the available space

  • i

    Preparation for Dentures

    Removing remaining damaged teeth before full denture placement

Types of Extractions

Simple Extraction

For teeth that are visible in the mouth and can be removed easily. Most routine extractions fall into this category.

Procedure:

  1. 1. Local anesthetic is administered
  2. 2. Tooth is loosened with dental instruments
  3. 3. Tooth is gently removed with forceps
  4. 4. Bleeding is controlled and healing instructions given

Recovery: 1-3 days with minimal discomfort

Surgical Extraction

For teeth that are broken at the gum line, impacted, or have complex root structures. Requires more advanced techniques.

Procedure:

  1. 1. Local anesthetic (possibly sedation)
  2. 2. Small incision in the gum tissue
  3. 3. Tooth may be sectioned for easier removal
  4. 4. Extraction site is cleaned and sutured

Recovery: 3-7 days with managed post-operative care

What to Expect During Your Procedure

Before

We'll review your medical history, take X-rays if needed, and explain the procedure. Local anesthetic ensures you're comfortable.

During

You'll feel pressure but no pain. Simple extractions typically take just a few minutes. We work efficiently while prioritizing your comfort.

After

We'll provide detailed aftercare instructions and prescribe any necessary medications. Follow-up appointments ensure proper healing.

Post-Extraction Care

What TO Do

  • Bite on gauze for 30-45 minutes to control bleeding
  • Apply ice packs for 15-20 minutes to reduce swelling
  • Take prescribed medications as directed
  • Eat soft foods and drink plenty of fluids
  • Rinse gently with salt water after 24 hours

What NOT to Do

  • Don't smoke or use tobacco products
  • Avoid drinking through straws
  • Don't spit forcefully or rinse vigorously
  • Avoid hard, crunchy, or spicy foods
  • Don't touch the extraction site with fingers or tongue

Replacement Options After Extraction

Dental Implants

Most natural-feeling permanent replacement option

Learn more →

Dental Bridge

Fixed replacement that uses adjacent teeth for support

Learn more →

Partial Denture

Removable option for replacing one or several teeth

Learn more →

Comfortable & Safe Tooth Extraction

When extraction is necessary, we make the process as comfortable as possible. We'll also help you explore the best replacement options to restore your smile.

Frequently Asked Questions

Will the tooth extraction hurt?

We use local anesthetic to ensure you're completely comfortable during the procedure. You may feel pressure but should not experience pain. After the procedure, any discomfort can usually be managed with over-the-counter pain relievers.

How long does it take to heal after an extraction?

Initial healing typically takes 1-2 weeks, with the socket forming a blood clot within 24 hours. Complete healing of the bone and gum tissue can take several months. Most patients return to normal activities within a few days.

What is dry socket and how can I prevent it?

Dry socket occurs when the blood clot is dislodged from the extraction site, causing severe pain. Prevent it by avoiding smoking, drinking through straws, spitting forcefully, and following all post-operative instructions carefully.

Can I eat normally after tooth extraction?

Start with soft foods like yogurt, soup, and smoothies for the first few days. Gradually reintroduce normal foods as comfort allows. Avoid hard, crunchy, or sticky foods near the extraction site during the initial healing period.
